title: POLITICO Brussels Playbook, presented by The Boeing Company: The von derlayed Commission — EUCO or cuckoo? — Nobel fury
text:
POLITICO Brussels Playbook, presented by The Boeing Company: The von derlayed Commission — EUCO or cuckoo? — Nobel fury

Press play to listen to this article Voiced by Amazon Polly

By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

with ZOYA SHEFTALOVICH

PRESENTED BY

Send tips here | Tweet @herszenhorn | Listen to Playbook and view in your browser

THE VON DERLAYED COMMISSION: The Ursula von der Leyen Commission will not take office on November 1, after a series of head-spinning events on Thursday shook Brussels and the EU institutions, and reverberated from Paris to Berlin, then to Bucharest and back. Put simply: a commissioner denied is a Commission delayed. We’ll get to the question of whether it was poetic justice, sweet revenge or something else in a moment. Mostly, it’s a mess.

First, a quick recap of a tumultuous Thursday: MEPs overwhelmingly rejected Sylvie Goulard, the French nominee to be commissioner for the EU’s internal market and industrial policy, including the defense and space sectors, after Goulard failed in two separate hearings to sufficiently explain allegations of financial misconduct, and a very high-paid consulting position with a U.S.-based think thank for which she did little work. The vote, by secret ballot, wasn’t even close: MEPs crushed her nomination 82 to 29.

That left von der Leyen 3 commissioners short of a full College (excluding the U.K.) — European Parliament previously rejected the Romanian and Hungarian nominees, also over ethical concerns. Adding to the mayhem, Romania’s governing coalition collapsed Thursday, making it impossible to predict when Bucharest might put forward a new candidate. In any event, getting three replacements vetted and confirmed by Parliament won’t happen in time for a plenary vote on the full College in Strasbourg the week after next. So, it now looks like the new Commission will take office the first week of December — at the earliest.

There’s always a bright side: At least von der Leyen can take solace knowing she won’t have to spend her first day as president in crisis mode if there’s a no-deal Brexit on October 31. That joyous duty would fall to Jean-Claude Juncker, battle-scarred survivor of the Greek debt crisis and migration mess. (Don’t forget, Juncker has promised to write Playbook on his last day in office, whenever that might be.)

GOOD MORNING, I’m David M. Herszenhorn, POLITICO’s chief Brussels correspondent, filling in for Florian. And, with my colleagues Maïa de La Baume and Laura Kayali in Brussels, and Rym Momtaz in Paris, we have pulled together all the details for you about Goulard’s doomed nomination here. Plus with our EU editor, Andrew Gray, we discuss Goulard on this week’s EU Confidential podcast here.

CONFIRMATION MAYHEM

THIS ONE’S GONNA HURT: Goulard’s rejection was a stinging betrayal of von der Leyen by her own conservative European People’s Party (EPP), which led the charge against the French liberal nominee. But it also deeply embarrassed French President Emmanuel Macron, who quickly professed surprise and confusion over the outcome, and complained that von der Leyen had assured him Goulard had the support of Parliament’s three main pro-EU political groups. The episode is a far more serious crisis for von der Leyen than it might initially seem, because it raises serious questions of trust among some of the EU’s biggest power players.

Awkward 1: Macron, seeming to duck blame for the debacle, said he had suggested three candidates to be French commissioner and it was von der Leyen who insisted on Goulard. (Video here.) He said von der Leyen assured him she had consulted with the group leaders — Manfred Weber of the EPP, Iratxe García of the Socialists & Democrats and Dacian Cioloș of her own Renew Europe. García and Weber quickly issued statements denying they’d been consulted about Goulard’s candidacy in advance. And a spokesman for von der Leyen said he could neither confirm nor deny Macron’s account. All of which means someone’s taking liberties with the truth …

Awkward 2: Weber was the EPP’s Spitzenkandidat (aka lead candidate), for the Commission presidency, but his bid was blocked by the liberal and social democrat leaders on the European Council, notably Macron. When German Chancellor Angela Merkel and other conservatives insisted the EPP keep the Commission presidency, the job went to von der Leyen. So by torpedoing Goulard’s nomination, was Weber taking revenge? And, if so, was it on Macron? On von der Leyen? On Merkel? On all three, and the world? EPP insiders said Goulard was rejected on substance, making any vengeance coincidental. But was it any less sweet?

Awkward 3: To put a twist on Tacitus, victory comes with 100 BFFs, but defeat is no one’s friend. Von der Leyen and Goulard are reportedly pals, but the Commission president-elect issued a bland statement after Thursday’s vote, expressing not one ounce of regret over Goulard’s defeat. (Goulard, by contrast, issued a statement thanking von der Leyen for her confidence.) For sure, it probably didn’t help that Goulard, flailing during her first hearing, resorted to lamely telling MEPs, “I’m clean!” Still, von der Leyen at least could have thanked the failed nominees for their willingness to serve. She didn’t.

Seen another way, Goulard’s defeat brought symmetry to the confirmation process, spilling liberal blood after Parliament rejected the Hungarian nominee, László Trócsányi, a conservative, and the Romanian nominee, Rovana Plumb, a social democrat.

Still, the entire episode raised serious questions … about von der Leyen’s leadership skills, given her silence throughout much of the confirmation process; about Macron’s judgment, especially when it comes to personnel in Brussels; and about the prospects of finding and maintaining a majority coalition in what is now a far more diverse and divided European Parliament.

The fallout is likely to continue. In France, Macron’s Renaissance delegation accused French MEPs from other parties of betraying Goulard. Even Italy’s far-right former interior minister, Matteo Salvini, weighed in, calling Goulard’s defeat “great news.”

What’s next for Goulard? She seems likely to return to her previous job at the Bank of France.

AROUND THE BLOC

SUSPECT PLANNED SYNAGOGUE MASSACRE: German authorities arrested a 27-year-old suspect in a shooting attack that left two people dead outside a synagogue in Halle on Wednesday, which was Yom Kippur, the holiest day in Judaism. The suspect, who live-streamed his crime, had 4 kilograms of explosives in his car and planned to “kill a large number of people,” Germany’s top prosecutor said. Louise Guillot has the story.

Stats: How terrorism in Europe breaks down by the numbers.

COMMISSION SENDS SLOVAKIA A ROMA WARNING: The European Commission has called on Slovakia to comply with EU rules on equal treatment of Roma schoolchildren. In announcing its decision to send a so-called reasoned opinion to Slovakia on Thursday, the Commission said “a disproportionate share of Roma children are placed in special schools or classes for children with mental disabilities” in Slovakia, adding that the children are also marginalized in mainstream education. “Slovakia now has two months to respond and take the relevant action; otherwise, the Commission may decide to refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the EU,” the Commission said.

POLAND’S NEW COAL MINING LAW: On Monday, Poland’s parliament is set to debate a divisive new law that gives the government additional powers in the process of planning new coal mines — and the ruling Law and Justice (PiS) party government can push through the legislation even if it loses power in Sunday’s election, Wojciech Kość reports.

SUMMIT PREPARATION

EUCO OR CUCKOO? EU officials and diplomats were already bracing for a wild summit when EU national leaders gather next week in Brussels — largely because they expect to be ensnared in a tough conversation about Brexit.

Could this be a breakthrough? Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar and U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson met in Thornton Hough on the Wirral, in northern England, on Thursday. Varadkar, who had been pessimistic about reaching a Brexit agreement, expressed new confidence that an accord was possible. Varadkar called the discussion “very positive and very promising,” but it was unclear what Johnson might have said to make the Irishman so optimistic. EU ambassadors, meanwhile, will meet on Friday to discuss Brexit at around noon in Brussels. Cristina Gallardo and Charlie Cooper have more.

BUT BREXIT ISN’T THE ONLY ITEM ON THE EUCO AGENDA: The Finnish presidency of the Council of the European Union told EU ambassadors on Wednesday that it will circulate a new paper on the bloc’s next long-term budget, known more formally as the multi-annual financial framework, three EU diplomats said.

Cheapskates: That announcement sparked anger as some in the room suspected the bottom level will still be a Hanseatic 1 percent of gross national income (GNI) — which, according to the Commission’s position taken in the meeting, is “extreme.” The argument is that the budget proposal aims at streamlining the EU’s spending and incorporates currently separate pots such as the European Development Fund. In short: Should Brexit not be enough to keep leaders engaged in a fight with one another, the big money questions are sure to spur debate and disputes. Bjarke Smith-Meyer and Hannah Brenton have the full details.

School is in session: Commission President-elect von der Leyen is planning to attend the leaders’ summit and could get her first, extremely uncomfortable and up-close look at what life will be like when her own native Germany, and her mentor, Angela Merkel, adopt positions that favor national interests over EU ones.

IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

ENLARGEMENT SNEAK PEEK: Commissioner for European Neighborhood Policy and Enlargement Negotiations Johannes Hahn told reporters on Thursday that “on our side, on the Commission side, we are very clear — very clear — that we expect [a] green light for the opening of accession negotiations with both countries, North Macedonia and Albania.” Hahn added: “Both countries have fulfilled their conditions, which were agreed unanimously by all EU member states in advance.”

Warning: Hahn, who is set to stay on in Brussels as the next budget and administration commissioner, urged EU governments who are hesitant about opening negotiations with the two countries to take into account the “geo-strategic element” and warned that if the EU does not deliver in the western Balkans, it will lose credibility and others will fill the vacuum.

TRUMP WORLD, NOW FEATURING UKRAINE

NO PRESSURE, NO BLACKMAIL, NOTHING TO SEE: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy held a marathon press conference on Thursday, during which he met with scores of journalists. He said he felt “no pressure” in his July phone call U.S. President Donald Trump, and insisted there was “no blackmail.” The call is at the center of an impeachment inquiry by Congress into whether Trump abused his office by asking the Ukrainians to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden’s son. Paul Dallison has more.

Sondland to testify next week: U.S. Ambassador to the EU Gordon Sondland is expected to testify next Wednesday before the House of Representatives committees investigating Trump and Ukraine, despite being blocked by the State Department, Axios reports.

Meanwhile … Two foreign-born associates of Trump’s personal lawyer, former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani, were arrested in the U.S. and indicted on charges of violating campaign finance laws. As Maggie Severns writes, foreign efforts to influence Trump keep piling up.

OPINION I — WOODY JOHNSON, PERSONA NON GRATA. In an op-ed for POLITICO, former British Ambassador Ivor Roberts explains what underpins diplomatic immunity, in the context of the case of Anne Sacoolas, the wife of a U.S. intelligence official who is a suspect in a fatal road crash in the U.K. Sacoolas’ flight out of the U.K. “could not have occurred without the permission — perhaps even at the suggestion — of U.S. Ambassador Woody Johnson, a close friend and supporter of Trump,” Roberts writes, suggesting that in return, London should label Johnson persona non grata.

OPINION II — AS US RETREATS FROM MIDDLE EAST, EUROPE MUST STEP UP: Donald Trump’s decision this week to provide a de-facto green light for another Turkish offensive into Kurdish-held territory in Northern Syria should serve as a shock that moves the EU to act, write Nathalie Tocci and Sinan Ekim in an op-ed for POLITICO.

Meanwhile, Turkish forces have escalated their campaign in Syria. The New York Times reports from Akçakale.

OVER AND OUT

AWARDED: Polish writer Olga Tokarczuk, the author of the Man Booker International winning novel “Flights,” has won the 2018 Nobel Prize for Literature, which was postponed after a scandal engulfed the jury last year. “The prize goes to Eastern Europe, which is unusual, incredible,” Tokarczuk told reporters ahead of a lecture in the German town of Bielefeld, according to Reuters. “For me as a Polish, it shows that despite all those problems with democracy in my country we still have something to say to the world,” she said, adding: “I would like to tell my friends, people in Poland, let’s vote in a right way for democracy,” referring to Poland’s election on Sunday.

But controversially, Austrian author Peter Handke, whom critics have slammed as a sympathizer for the genocidal Milošević regime, was awarded the 2019 literature prize. “Never thought would feel to vomit because of a @NobelPrize,” tweeted Albanian PM Edi Rama. “We can’t become so numb to racism&genocide!” Albania’s Acting Foreign Minister also didn’t mince words. “As a passionate believer in literature’s eternal beauty&power to enrich human experience&as a victim of ethnic cleansing&genocide, I’m appalled by the decision to award @NobelPrize in literature to a genocide denier,” he tweeted. “What an ignoble & shameful act we are witnessing in 2019!”

BIRTHDAYS: MEPs François-Xavier Bellamy and Gilles Lebreton; Former MEPs Mady Delvaux and Ricardo Serrão Santos; French Minister Gérald Darmanin; Prince Constantijn of the Netherlands.

THANKS TO: Jacopo Barigazzi, Maïa de La Baume, Lili Bayer, Laura Kayali, Rym Momtaz, Daniel Lippman, Florian Eder and our producer Miriam Webber.

CORRECTION: This newsletter was updated to correct the name of the fund that is currently separate from the multiannual financial framework but which the European Commission has suggested be integrated into the next 2021-2027 EU budget. It is the European Development Fund.
